Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I will be a park-attendant.'

This, monks, is a declaration of weakness and the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I will be a novice.'

This, monks, is a declaration of weakness and the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I will be an adherent of another sect.'

This, monks, is a declaration of weakness and the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I will be a disciple of another sect.'

This, monks, is a declaration of weakness and the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I will not be a recluse.'

This, monks, is a declaration of weakness and the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I will not be a son of the Sakyans.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

 

 

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the enlightened one.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the Dhamma.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the Order.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the training.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the discipline.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the Pāṭimokkha.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the exposition.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the preceptor.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the teacher.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of my fellow monks.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the novice.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the preceptors of my equals.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the teachers of my equals.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am tired of the Brahma-life.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

 

 

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the enlightened one to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the Dhamma to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the Order to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the training to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the discipline to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the Pāṭimokkha to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the exposition to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the preceptor to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the teacher to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What are my fellow monks to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the novice to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What are the preceptors of my equals to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What are the teachers of my equals to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'What is the Brahma-life to me?'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

 

 

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The enlightened one means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The Dhamma means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The Order means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The training means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The discipline means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The Pāṭimokkha means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The exposition means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The preceptor means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The teacher means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'My fellow monks mean nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The novice means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The preceptors of my equals mean nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The teachers of my equals mean nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'The Brahma-life means nothing to me.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

 

 

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the enlightened one.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the Dhamma.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the Order.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the training.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the discipline.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the Pāṭimokkha.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the exposition.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the preceptor.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the teacher.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to my fellow monks.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the novice.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the preceptors of my equals.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the teachers of my equals.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

Then further, a monk who is chafing, dissatisfied, desirous of passing from the state of a recluse, anxious, troubled and ashamed at being a monk, longing to be a householder, longing to be a lay-follower, longing to be a park-attendant, longing to be a novice, longing to belong to another sect, longing to be a disciple of another sect, longing not to be a recluse, longing not to be a son of the Sakyans, says and declares:

'I am well freed with regard to the Brahma-life.'

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weaknesswith the training being disavowed.

 

 

Then there are these other attributes of the enlightened one,
or of dhamma,
or of the Order,
or of the training,
or of the discipline,
or of the Pāṭimokkha,
or of the exposition,
or of the the receptor,
or of the the teacher,
or of his fellow monks,
or of the novice,
or of the preceptors of his equals,
or of the teachers of his equals,
or of the the Brahma-life,
or of the the householder,
or of the the lay-follower,
or of the the park=attendant,
or of the the novice,
or of the the adherent of another sect,
or of the the disciple of another sect,
or of the the recluse,
or of the one who is a son of the Sakyans;
he speaks, he declares by reason of these properties, by reason of these features, by reason of these signs.

Thus, monks, there is a declaration of weakness, the training having been disavowed. [|3|]

 

 

And how, monks, is the training not disavowed?

Here, monks, by reason of these properties, by reason of these features, by reason of these signs, the training is disavowed, yet if one who is out of his mind disavows the training by reason of these properties, by reason of these features, by reason of these signs, then the training is not disavowed.

If one disavows the training in the presence of one who is out of his mind, the training is not disavowed.

If one whose mind is unhinged disavows [47] the training is not disavowed.

If one disavows the training in the presence of one whose mind is unhinged, the training is not disavowed.

If one is afflicted with pain and disavows the training, the training is not disavowed.

If one disavows the training in the presence of one afflicted by pain, the training is not disavowed.

If one disavows the training in the presence of devatas,[170] the training is not disavowed.

If one disavows the training in the presence of animals, the training is not disavowed.

If an ariyan[171] disavows the training in the presence of a non-ariyan[172] and he does not recognise it, the training is not disavowed.

If a non-ariyan disavows the training in the presence of an ariyan and he does not recognise it, the training is not disavowed.

If an ariyan disavows the training in the presence of an ariyan and he does not recognise it, the training is not disavowed.

If a non-ariyan [27] disavows the training in the presence of a non-ariyan and he does not recognise it, the training is not disavowed.

If he disavows the training for a joke, the training is not disavowed.

If he disavows the training for fun, the training is not disavowed.

If he announces what he does not wish to announce, the training is not disavowed.

If he does not announce what he wishes to announce, the training is not disavowed.

If he announces to those not knowing, the training is not disavowed.

If he does not announce to those knowing, the training is not disavowed.

If he does not announce the whole thing, the training is not disavowed.

This, monks, is the training which is not disavowed. [|4|]

 

 

Sexual intercourse means: what is not verily dhamma, village dhamma, low-caste dhamma, wickedness, the final ablution, secrecy, having obtained in couples: this is called sexual intercourse.

Indulges means: whenever the male organ is made to enter the female, the male member to enter the female, even for the length of a fruit of the sesame plant, this is called indulges.

Even with an animal means: indulging in sexual intercourse with a female animal,[173] he is not a (true) recluse, [48] not a (true) son of the Sakyans, much less so than with women: hence the meaning is even with an animal.

Is one who is defeated means: as a man with his head cut off cannot become[174] one to live with that bodily connection, so is a monk indulging in sexual intercourse not a (true) recluse, not a (true) son of the Sakyans[175]: therefore he is called one who is defeated.

Is not in communion means: communion[176] is called one work, one rule, an equal training, this is called communion.

He who is not together with this is therefore called not in communion. [|5|] [8]

■

Three kinds of females: human women, non-human females, female animals.

Three kinds of hermaphrodites: human hermaphrodites, non-human hermaphrodites, animal hermaphrodites.

Three kinds of eunochs: human eunuchs, non-human eunuchs, animal eunuchs.

Three kinds of males: human males, non-human males, animal males.

 

 

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in three passages of a human woman: in the rectum, in the vagina, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in three passages of a non-human female: in the rectum, in the vagina, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in three passages of a female animal: in the rectum, in the vagina, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in three passages of a human hermaphrodite: in the rectum, in the vagina, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in three passages of a non-human hermaphrodite: in the rectum, in the vagina, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in three passages of an animal hermaphrodite animal: in the rectum, in the vagina, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in two passages of a human eunuch: in the rectum, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in two passages of a non-human eunuch: in the rectum, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in two passages of an animal eunuch: in the rectum, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in two passages of a human male: in the rectum, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in two passages of a non-human male: in the rectum, in the mouth."

"There is an offence involving defeat for him who indulges in sexual intercourse in two passages of a male animal: in the rectum, in the mouth." [|1|] [28]

 

 

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human woman in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human woman in the vagina, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human woman in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

[49]

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human woman in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human woman in the vagina, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human woman in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a female animal in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a female animal in the vagina, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a female animal in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human hermaphrodite in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human hermaphrodite in the vagina, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human hermaphrodite in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human hermaphrodite in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human hermaphrodite in the vagina, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human hermaphrodite in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter an animal hermaphrodite in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter an animal hermaphrodite in the vagina, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter an animal hermaphrodite in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human eunuch in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human eunuch in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human eunuch in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human eunuch in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter an animal eunuch in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter an animal eunuch in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human male in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a human male in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human male in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a non-human male in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a male animal in the rectum, there is an offence involving defeat.

For a monk who, having thought of cohabitation, lets his male organ enter a male animal in the mouth, there is an offence involving defeat. [|2|]

 

 

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her vagina.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to withdraw,

there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human eunuch into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his rectum.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal male mad into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his mouth.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal male drunk into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his rectum.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal male dead and practically decomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his rectum.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal male dead and practically decomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his mouth.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence. [|3|]

 

 

Covered/uncovered

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman [30] into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the woman being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her vagina, the woman being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman dead and practically undecomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her mouth, the woman being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

but agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a female animal into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the female animal being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,

agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a non-human hermaphrodite intoxicated into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite mad into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her vagina, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human eunuch dead and practically decomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his mouth, the eunuch being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a non-human eunuch into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his rectum, the eunuch being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal eunuch dead but undecomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his rectum, the eunuch being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a non-human male mad into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with his rectum, the non-human male being covered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

Uncovered/covered

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the woman being uncovered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her vagina, the woman being uncovered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to withdraw,

If he does not agree to enter,

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a human woman awake into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the woman being uncovered, the monk covered.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a non-human female asleep into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her mouth, the non-human female being uncovered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a female animal mad into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the female animal being uncovered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a non-human hermaphrodite dead but undecomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her mouth, the hermaphrodite being uncovered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite dead and practically decomposed into a monk's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the hermaphrodite being uncovered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.
