there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human hermaphrodite mad, associate his male organ with her vagina, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a non-human hermaphrodite drunk, associate his male organ with her vagina, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite dead but undecomposed, associate his male organ with her mouth, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite dead and practically undecomposed, associate his male organ with her rectum, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite dead and practically undecomposed, associate his male organ with her vagina, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite dead and practically decomposed, associate his male organ with her rectum, the hermaphrodite being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human eunuch, associate his male organ with his rectum, the eunuch being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human eunuch, associate his male organ with his mouth, the eunuch being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a non-human eunuch intoxicated, associate his male organ with his mouth, the eunuch being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,

but agrees to remain,

but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human male awake, associate his male organ with his rectum, the human male being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a non-human male dead and practically decomposed, associate his male organ with his rectum, the eunuch being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a non-human male dead and practically decomposed, associate his male organ with his mouth, the non-human male being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal, associate his male organ with his rectum, the male animal being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal, associate his male organ with his mouth, the male animal being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal awake, associate his male organ with his rectum, the male animal being covered, the monk covered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to withdraw,

Uncovered/Uncovered II

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into a human woman's presence, associate his male organ with her rectum, the woman being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into a human woman's presence, associate his male organ with her vagina, the woman being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human woman intoxicated, associate his male organ with her mouth, the woman being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to withdraw,

agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a non-human female drunk, associate his male organ with her vagina, the non-human female being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to remain,

but agrees to withdraw,

and does not agree to remain,

there is no offence.

and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a female animal dead but undecomposed, associate his male organ with her mouth, the female animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to withdraw,

there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human hermaphrodite dead and practically decomposed, associate his male organ with her rectum, the hermaphrodite being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal hermaphrodite, associate his male organ with her vagina, the hermaphrodite being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human eunuch asleep, associate his male organ with his mouth, the eunuch being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal eunuch, associate his male organ with his rectum, the eunuch being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought an animal eunuch, associate his male organ with his mouth, the eunuch being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a human male dead and practically undecomposed, associate his male organ with his rectum, the human male being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal drunk, associate his male organ with his rectum, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal drunk, associate his male organ with his mouth, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal dead but undecomposed, associate his male organ with his rectum, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal dead but undecomposed, associate his male organ with his mouth, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal dead and practically undecomposed, associate his male organ with his rectum, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal dead and practically undecomposed, associate his male organ with his mouth, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is an offence involving defeat.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal dead and practically decomposed, associate his male organ with his rectum, the eunuch being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence.

■

Opponents of monks, having brought a monk into the presence of a male animal dead and practically decomposed, associate his male organ with his mouth, the male animal being uncovered, the monk uncovered.

If he agrees to enter,
if he agrees to having entered,
if he agrees to remain,
if he agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
but agrees to having entered,
agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
but agrees to remain,
agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
but agrees to withdraw,
there is a grave offence.

If he does not agree to enter,
and does not agree to having entered,
and does not agree to remain,
and does not agree to withdraw,
there is no offence. [|5|] [|6|]

 

 

In as much as opponents of monks have been explained, so should be explained opponents as kings, opponents as thieves, opponents as scoundrels, opponents as "the scent of lotuses."[177]

Covered has been commented upon.

■

He lets the way enter by the way, there is an offence involving defeat.

He lets what is not the way enter by the way, there is an offence involving defeat.

He lets the way enter by what is not the way, there is an offence involving defeat.

He lets what is not the way enter by what is not the way, there is a grave offence.

 

 

A monk commits sin with a sleeping monk.

Awakened he agrees; both should be expelled.[178]

Awakened he does not agree; the defiler [51] should be expelled.

■

A monk commits sin with a sleeping novice.

Awakened he agrees; both should be expelled.

Awakened he does not agree; the defiler should be expelled.

■

A novice commits sin with a sleeping monk.

Awakened he agrees; both should be expelled.

Awakened he does not agree; the defiler should be expelled.

■

A novice commits sin with a sleeping novice.

Awakened he agrees; both should be expelled.

Awakened he does not agree; the defiler should be expelled. [|7|]

■

If one is ignorant, if one has not agreed, if one is mad, unhinged, afflicted with pain, or a beginner, there is no offence. [|8|][|9|]

Told is the Recital on Covering.

 

 

The female monkey, and sons of the Vajjins, a householder and a naked one, adherents of another sect,
The girl, and Uppalavanna, then two about characteristics,
Mother, daughter, and sister, and wife, supple, pendent, [33]
Two sores, and a plaster decoration, and a wooden doll,
Five with Sundara,[179] five about cemeteries, bones,
A female naga and a female yakkha, and a female peta, a eunuch, impaired, he touched,
In Bhaddiya, the man perfected, asleep, then four on Sāvatthī,
Three on Vesālī, garlands,[180] the Bharukaccha monk in his dream,
[52] Supabbā, Saddhā, a nun, a female probationer, and a female novice,
A prostitute, a eunuch, a householder, one another, one who had gone forth when old, a deer.

 

 

Now at that time a certain monk indulged in sexual intercourse with a female monkey.

On account of this he was remorseful.

He said, "The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."[181]

He told this matter to the lord.

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said. [|1|]

■

Now at that time a great company of monks, dwellers in Vesālī, and of the Vajji clan, not disavowing the training and not declaring their weakness, indulged in sexual intercourse.

On account of this they were remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

Let us hope that we have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

They told this matter to the lord."

You, monks, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said. [|21]

■

Now at that time, a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," committed sexual intercourse (wearing) the characteristic (white dress) of a layman.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk being naked committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a kusa-grass garment[182] [53] committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a bark garment[183] committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a garment of wood shavings[183] committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a hair blanket[184] committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a blanket made of horse-hair committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a dress of owls' wings committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said.

■

Now at that time a certain monk saying:

"There will be no offence for me," clad in a cloak made of strips of a black antelope's hide,[185] committed sexual intercourse, saying:

"There will be no offence for me."

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

You, monk, have fallen into an offence entailing defeat," he said. [|3|]

■

Now at one time a certain monk as he was wandering for alms, seeing a little girl lying on her back, sexually aroused (saratto) inserted (pavesesi) his thumb into her female organ, and she died.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord."

"Monk, there is not an offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order,"[186] he said. [|4|] [34]

■

Now at one time a certain brahmin youth was in love with the nun Uppalavanna.[187]

Then this brahmin youth, [54] when the nun Uppalavanna had gone into the village for alms, entered the hut and sat down, concealed.

The nun Uppalavanna, after the meal and when she had finished eating, washing her feet and entering the hut, sat down on the couch.

Then the brahmin youth, taking up the nun Uppalavanna, assaulted her.

The nun Uppalavanna told this matter to the nuns.

The nuns told this matter to the monks.[188]

The monks told this matter to the lord.

He said:

"There is no offence, monks, as she was not willing." [|5|]

■

Now at one time the sign of a woman[189] appeared to a monk.

They told this matter to the lord.

He said:

"Monks, I allow a teacher[190] to meet with the nuns during the rains, as for the upasampada ordination, so as in the presence of nuns to turn the nuns away from those offences which they have in common with monks; but in those offences of monks which are offences not in common with nuns, there is no offence (for the nuns)."

■

Now at that time the sign of a male appeared to a nun.

They told this matter to the lord.

He said:

"Monks, I allow a teacher to meet with the monks during the rains, as for the upasampada ordination, so as in the presence of monks to turn the monks away from those offences which they have in common with nuns, but in those offences of nuns which are offences not in common with monks, there is no offence (for the monks)." [|6|]

[55]

■

Now at that time, a certain monk thinking:

"There will be no offence for me," indulged in sexual intercourse with his mother.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time, a certain monk thinking:

"There will be no offence for me," indulged in sexual intercourse with his daughter.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time, a certain monk thinking:

"There will be no offence for me," indulged in sexual intercourse with his sister.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time, a certain monk indulged in sexual intercourse with his former wife.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|7|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk had a supple back.[191]

Tormented by chafing,[192] he took hold of his own male organ with his mouth.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk was able to bend down his male organ.

Tormented by chafing,[192] he inserted his male organ into his rectum.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|8|] [35]

■

Now at that time a certain monk saw a dead body, and on the body was a sore around the female organ.

He, thinking:

"There will be no offence for me,", inserted his male organ into the female organ [and] withdrew it from the sore.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk saw a dead body, and on this body was a sore around the female organ.

He, thinking, "There will be no offence for me", inserted his male organ into the sore [and] withdrew it from the female organ.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|9|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk, sexually aroused, touched with his male organ the sexual organ of [a figure made of] plaster.[193]

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, this is not an offence involving defeat, this is an offence of wrong-doing."

■

Now at that time a certain monk, sexually aroused, touched with his male organ the sexual organ of a wooden doll.[194]

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, this is not an offence involving defeat, this is an offence of wrong-doing."

[56]

■

Now at that time the monk called Sundara, who had gone forth from Rājagaha, was walking along a carriage-road.

A certain woman said:

"Wait, honoured sir, for a moment, I will pay homage to you."

As she was paying homage she held up his inner garment and took hold of his male organ with her mouth.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

Monk, did you agree?"

"I did not agree, lord," he said.[195]

"There is no offence, monk, as you did not agree." [|11|]

■

Now at that time a certain woman seeing a monk, spoke thus:

"Come, honoured sir, indulge in sexual intercourse."

"Not so, sister, that is not proper for me."

"Come, honoured sir, I will exert myself, do not you exert yourself, thus there will be no offence for you."

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain woman seeing a monk, spoke thus:

"Come, honoured sir, indulge in sexual intercourse."

"Not so, sister, that is not proper for me."

"Come, honoured sir, you exert yourself, I will not exert myself, thus there will be no offence for you."

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at one time a certain woman seeing a monk, spoke thus:

"Come, honoured sir, indulge in sexual intercourse."

"Not so, sister, that is not proper for me."

"Come, honoured sir, having rubbed within, emit [semen] outside.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at one time a certain woman seeing a monk, spoke thus:

"Come, honoured sir, indulge in sexual intercourse."

"Not so, sister, that is not proper for me."

"Come, honoured sir, having rubbed outside, emit [semen] within.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|12|]

■

Now at one time a certain monk going to a cemetery and seeing a body not yet decomposed indulged in sexual intercourse [57] [36] with it.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at one time a certain monk going to a cemetery and seeing a body which was practically undecomposed indulged in sexual intercourse with it.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at one time a certain monk going to a cemetery and seeing a body which was practically decomposed indulged in sexual intercourse with it.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat, there is a grave offence."

■

Now at one time a certain monk going to a cemetery and seeing a decapitated head, inserted his male organ into the opened mouth touching [it].

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at one time a certain monk going to a cemetery and seeing a decapitated head, inserted his male organ into the opened mouth not touching [it].

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, this is not an offence involving defeat; this is an offence of wrong-doing."

■

Now at that time a certain monk was in love with a certain woman.

She died, and her bones were thrown in the charnel-ground and scattered.

Then the monk, going to the cemetery, collected the bones and put his male organ in [her] sexual organ.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

Monk, there is no offence involving defeat, there is an offence of wrong-doing." [|13|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk indulged in sexual intercourse with a female naga.[196]

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk indulged in sexual intercourse with a female yakkha,[197]

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk indulged in sexual intercourse with a female departed one.[198]

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk indulged in sexual intercourse with a [58] a eunuch.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|14|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk's faculties were impaired.[199]

Saying:

"I feel neither ease nor discomfort, thus there will be no offence for me," he indulged in sexual intercourse.

They told this matter to the lord.

He said:

"Monks, whether this foolish man felt or did not feel,[200] there is an offence involving defeat." [|15|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk, saying:

"I will indulge in sexual intercourse with a woman," was conscience-stricken at the mere touch.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat, there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order." [|16|].

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down in the Jātiyā Grove at Bhaddiya,[201] having gone there for the day-sojourn.

All his limbs were stiff with pain.

A certain woman seeing him, sat down on his male organ, and having taken her pleasure, departed.

The monks, seeing that he was wet,[202] told this matter to the lord. [37]

He said, "Five things cause the male organ to be ready [for ejaculation]: sexual passion, excrements, urine, winds, the bite of a kind of vermin.

These five things, monks, cause the male organ to be ready [for ejaculation].

It is not possible, monks, it cannot come to pass that this monk's male organ should be ready [for ejaculation] by sexual passion.

Monks, this monk is a man perfected; monks, there is no offence for this monk." [|17|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down, having gone to the Dark Wood at Sāvatthī for the day-sojourn.

A certain woman cowherd seeing him, sat down on his male organ.

The monk agreed to enter, he agreed to having entered, he agreed to remain, he agreed to withdraw [his penis].

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down, having gone to the Dark Wood at Sāvatthī for the day-sojourn.

A certain woman goatherd seeing him, sat down on his male organ.

The monk agreed to enter, he agreed to having entered, he agreed to remain, he agreed to withdraw [his penis].

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down, having gone to the Dark Wood at Sāvatthī for the day-sojourn.

A certain woman gathering fire-wood seeing him, sat down on his male organ.

The monk agreed to enter, he agreed to having entered, he agreed to remain, he agreed to withdraw [his penis].

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat."

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down, having gone to the Dark Wood at Sāvatthī for the day-sojourn.

A certain [59] woman gathering cow-dung seeing him, sat down on his male organ.

The monk agreed to enter, he agreed to having entered, he agreed to remain, he agreed to withdraw [his penis].

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|18|]

■

Now at one time a certain monk was lying down, having gone into the Great Wood at Vesālī for the day-sojourn.

A certain woman seeing him, sat down on his male organ, and having taken her pleasure, stood laughing near by.

The monk, waking up, spoke thus to this woman:

"Have you done this?'

"Yes, I have," she said.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, did you consent?"

"I did not know, lord," he said.

"Monk, there is no offence as you did not know." [|19|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down, resting against a tree, having gone into the Great Wood at Vesālī for the day-sojourn.

A certain woman, seeing him, sat down on his male organ.

The monk got up hastily.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

Monk, did you consent?"

"I did not consent, lord," he said.

"Monk, there is no offence as you did not consent."

■

Now at that time a certain monk was lying down, resting against a tree, having gone into the Great Wood at Vesālī for the day-sojourn.

A certain woman, seeing him, sat down on his male organ..

The monk, rising (quickly), knocked her over.[203]

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, did you consent?"

"I did not consent, lord," he said.

"Monk, there is no offence as you did not consent." [|20|]

[6o]

■

Now at that time a certain monk, in the Gabled Hall in the Great Wood at Vesālī for his day-sojoum, was lying down having opened the door.

All his limbs were stiff with pains.

Now at that time a large company of women, bringing scents [38] and garlands, came to the park looking at the vihāra.

Then these women seeing that monk, sat down on his male organ, and having taken their pleasure and saying:

"Isn't he a bull of a man[204]?" departed, piling up their scents and garlands.

The monks, seeing the moisture, told this matter to the lord.

He said, "Five things cause the male organ to be ready [for ejaculation]: sexual passion, excrements, urine, winds, the bite of a kind of vermin.

These five things, monks, cause the male organ to be ready [for ejaculation].

It is not possible, monks, it cannot come to pass that this monk's male organ should be ready [for ejaculation] by sexual passion.

Monks, this monk is a man perfected; monks, there is no offence for this monk."

I allow you, monks, when you are in seclusion for meditation during the day, to meditate in seclusion, having closed the door." [|21|]

■

Now at that time a certain monk of Bharukaccha,[205] having dreamed that he committed sexual intercourse with his former wife, said:

"I am not a (true) recluse, I will leave the Order,"[206] and going to Bharukaccha, and seeing the venerable Upali[207] on the road, he told him [6l] this matter.

The venerable Upali said:

"There is no offenoe, your reverence, since it was in a dream." [|22|]

■

Now at that time in Rājagaha there was a female lay-follower, called Supabba,[208] who believed in the enlightened one.

She held this view: whatever (woman) gives sexual intercourse, gives the highest gift.

Seeing a monk she spoke thus:

"Come, honoured sir, indulge in sexual intercourse."

"Not so, sister, it is not fitting," he said.

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the region of the breasts, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the navel, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the stomach, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the waist, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the the throat, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the ear, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the the coil of hair, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the spaces between the fingers, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, masturbating [your penis] with [my] hand, I will make [you] ejaculate, thus there will be no offcnce for you."

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order." [|23|]

■

Now at that time at Sāvatthī was a female lay-disciple, called Saddhā, who believed in the enlightened one.

She held this view: whatever (woman) gives sexual intercourse, gives the highest gift.

Seeing a monk she spoke thus:

"Come, honoured sir, indulge in sexual intercourse."

"Not so, sister, it is not fitting," he said.

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the region of the breasts, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the navel, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the stomach, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the waist, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the the throat, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the the coil of hair, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, (only) touch the spaces between the fingers, thus there will be no offence for you.

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order."

■

"Come, honoured sir, masturbating [your penis] with [my] hand, I will make [you] ejaculate, thus there will be no offcnce for you."

The monk acted accordingly.

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, there is no offence involving defeat; there is an offence entailing a formal meeting of the Order." [|24|]

 

 

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths, taking hold of a monk, made him commit sin with a [62] nun. [39]

Both agreed, then both should be expelled.[209]

Neither agreed, there was no offence for either.

■

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths, taking hold of a monk, made him commit sin with a female probationer.

Both agreed, then both should be expelled.

Neither agreed, there was no offence for either.

■

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths, taking hold of a monk, made him commit sin with a female novice.

Both agreed, then both should be expelled.

Neither agreed, there was no offence for either.

 

 

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths* taking hold of a monk, made him commit sin with a prostitute.[210]

The monk agreed, then the monk should be expelled.

The monk did not agree, then there is no offence for the monk.

■

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths taking hold of a monk, made him commit sin with a eunuch.

The monk agreed, then the monk should be expelled.

The monk did not agree, then there is no offence for the monk.

■

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths taking hold of a monk, made him commit sin with a woman householder.

The monk agreed, then the monk should be expelled.

The monk did not agree, then there is no offence for the monk.

■

Now at that time at Vesālī some Licchavi youths taking hold of (some) monks made them commit sin with one another.

Both agreed, then both should be expelled.

Neither agreed, there is no offence for either. [|25|]

 

 

Now at that time a certain monk who had long gone forth, went to see his former wife.

She said, "Come, honoured sir, leave the Order,"[211] and she took hold of him.

The monk, stepping backwards, fell down on his back.[212]

She, bending him up,[213] sat down on his male organ..

On account of this he was remorseful, and said:

"The course of training has been made known by the lord.

I hope that I have not fallen into an offence entailing defeat."

He told this matter to the lord, who said:

"Monk, did you consent?"

"I did not consent, lord," he said.

"There is no offence, monk, as you did not consent." [|26|]

 

 

Now at that time a certain monk dwelt in the jungle.

A young deer, approaching the place where he urinated, took hold of his male organ with its mouth and drank the urine.

[63] The Monk concented.

On account of this he was remorseful.

He told this matter to the lord.

He said:

"You, monk, have fallen into an offence involving defeat." [|27|] |10|

Told is the First Offence involving Defeat[214].

[40]

[1] From here to end of [|1|] cf. AN IV 173-179.

[2] Quoted at DA. I 12. VA. 108 merely says that Verañjā was the name of a town. It is mentioned again at AN IV 172, 197. At AN II 57 it is said that Gotama was "journeying along the highroad between Madhurā and Verañjā." For Madhurā on the Jumna see Buddhist India, p. 36; C.H.I. i. 316. M. Sta. 42 says that Gotama addressed some brahmins and householders from Verañjā at Sāvatthī.

[3] VA. 108 says that here the yakkha is called Naḷeru, that pucimanda is the nimba-tree (Azadirachta Indica), and that mūlaṃ is samīpaṃ. Cf. Pucimandajātaka, Jā. iii., p. 33.

[4] VA. III, mātāpitūhi katanāmavasena panāyam Udayo ti vuccati.

[5] See Intr., p. xxxviii.

[6] See Intr., p. 1 ff.

[7] Sakyaputta, lit. son of the Sakyan(s), but a Pali idiom meaning simply "a Sakyan."

[8] Cf. DN. I 87.

[9] Arahan.

[10] All this is stock.

[11] Bho. This is the vocative, sing, and plur., of bhavant. See Intr., p. xxxviii.
